articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Vector Borne Disease
articles.description: A website on the effects of changing temperature on the spread of Vector Borne Diseases
articles.contents:
Introduction
West Nile and Lyme Disease are both examples of vector borne
diseases. Vector borne diseases are diseases that are transmitted by the
bite of an infected animal. Specifically for West Nile and Lyme, a
mosquito bite and a tick bite respectively are capable of transmitting
the virus into a human host to cause the disease.
However, both mosquitoes and ticks are sensitive to their
environment. Specifically, changing temperature can change how well
mosquitoes or ticks are able to survive and thrive. This changes the
number of active mosquitoes or ticks that can transmit these viruses,
thus impacting the number of cases that appear. In this website, I will
try to explore this relationship by comparing annual average
temperatures the number of cases of each disease in the US.
West Nile Disease
West Nile Disease is spread by mosquito bites. Specifically for
mosquitoes, higher temperatures creates optimal conditions for them to
thrive, allowing them to:
Remain active for more parts of the year
Develop at a faster rate to reach full adulthood
These conditions allow mosquitoes to proliferate earlier and for
longer periods of time. This gives mosquitoes more opportunities to
spread the West Nile Virus, thus increasing the number of cases.
Of course, this is how this is supposed to work on paper. In reality,
there are a multitude of other variables that are contribute to how well
mosquitoes are able to transmit West Nile, something which can be seen
and is explained in the West Nile Disease section of this website.
Lyme Disease
Comparatively, Lyme Disease is spread by tick bites. While higher
temperatures are great for mosquitoes, they are not ideal for ticks.
Specifically, the black-legged tick, the type of tick that spreads Lyme
Disease, high temperatures cause them to become less active as they
prefer cooler temperatures, typically between 4 and 25 degrees Celsius
(39.2 to 77 degrees Fahrenheit).
Therefore, higher temperatures can both be beneficial and detrimental
for ticks. Higher temperatures in cold areas, can create a climate ideal
for ticks to survive thus increasing their ability to spread Lyme
Disease. However higher temperatures in warm areas can create overly hot
climates that can reduce tick activity, reducing their ability to spread
Lyme Disease.
Again however, this is only how it works on paper. In reality, other
variables are also at play which change how well ticks are able to
thrive in a given area, something which can be seen and is explained in
the Lyme Disease section of this website.
